sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:

  • Tuberculosis: 15 to 30 mg/kg ORALLY once daily (MAX, 2000 mg/day) OR 50 mg/kg ORALLY 2 times a week (MAX, 4000 mg/day) in combination with other antitubercular agents

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment (CrCl less than 30 mL/min) 25 to 35 mg/kg 3 times a week; alternatively, (CrCl 10 mL/min or greater) usual dose of 25 to 30 mg/kg every 24 hours OR (CrCl less than 10 mL/min) 50% to 100% of usual dose every 24 hours
  • hemodialysis: 25 to 35 mg/kg 3 times a week after dialysis: alternatively, 25 to 30 mg/kg after dialysis

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• diabetes mellitus; disease management may be more difficult
  • drug resistance, suspected; susceptibility tests recommended
  • hepatocellular damage; discontinue use and do not resume if signs occur
  • hyperuricemia with acute gouty arthritis; discontinue use and do not resume if signs occur
  • liver disease, preexisting, or increased risk of drug-related hepatitis (eg, alcohol abusers); monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Pyrazinamide, a nicotinamide analogue, is an antituberculous agent. Pyrazinamide may be bacteriostatic or bactericidal, depending on the concentration and the susceptibility of the organism, although the exact mechanism is unknown. It is active in vitro at an acidic pH of 5.6 or less, similar to that found in early, active tubercular inflammatory lesions .

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 0.75 to 4 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: rapidly and almost completely absorbed
  • Effect of food: Cmax decreased by 17%, Tmax increased 80%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver: primary site via hydrolysis
  • Pyrazinoic acid: active

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• Pyrazinamide: adults, 9 to 10 hours
  • Pyrazinamide: children (age 0.3 to 11 years), 6.7 hours
  • Pyrazinamide: cirrhosis, 15 hours
  • Pyrazinamide: end stage renal disease, 26 hours
  • Pyrazinoic acid: adults, 12.3 hours
  • Pyrazinoic acid: cirrhosis, 24 hours

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• chest X-ray, sputum, symptomatic improvement
  • liver function tests, baseline and periodically during therapy
  • uric acid levels, baseline and periodically during therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause nausea, vomiting, or arthralgia.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of hepatotoxicity or gout.
